Hi all,

I'm starting to think about direction for the next SharpNEAT
iteration. There's been a lot of talk recently about novelty search
versus objective search, and maybe mixtures of the two. I myself
talked about how in the natural world organisms are separated in both
behavioural space (i.e. novel behaviour is less likely to compete for
the same resources as existing behaviours) but also geographical
space, and I think that geographical space is a key factor that is
missing from NEAT based search currently, and possibly EC as a whole,
with the caveat there may be other research groups with work in that
area that I'm unaware of.

My current plan is to focus on this geographical space idea for this
iteration because it is the simplest to implement. Dealing with
behavioural space is potentially more complicated because how to
compare behaviour varies across problem domains and how you identify
the key factors to compare is probably a non-trivial problem. I want
to try and tackle this at some point, but I'm also keen to explore the
geo-space idea.

What does this all mean in practical terms?

SharpNEAT is a kit of parts that allows you to swap in replacement
parts such as an alternative genetic representation and/or associated
genetic operators (recombination, mutation, etc) with minimal impact
on other parts in the kit (in principle anyway). I'm proposing to
provide an alternative evolution algorithm class that replaces NEAT's
genome based speciation (which clusters genomes into K clusters in
genetic space), with a geographical space alternative (I'll call it
geo-space for short).

The idea is that we have some cartesian/euclidean space (probably a
square 2D space initially to keep the code simple, but 3D or 'globe'
space (2-sphere) are reasonable alternatives). The seed genomes are
each assigned a random coord in the geo-space and this will be fixed
for the life of that genome. So we are basically adding a physical
attribute to the genome such that our population members are probably
better referred to as organisms (or agents or population members).
I'll use 'agent' because it's easier to type :)

Agent fitness is now adjusted by population density at the agent's
geo-location, this allows really bad agents to survive so long as they
are in a sparse region of geo-space, thus allowing for some diversity
of the genome pool.

Reproduction - I haven't put much thought into this but the two
options I see are to create offspring agents near to their parent(s)
versus randomly scattered. Probably some 'dispersion' variable will
define the amount of scattering with 0 being atop of the parent (or
between the two?) and 1 being totally random. (Question: Is e.g. seed
scattering in nature gaussian?). Clearly if agent's are spawned near
their parent's we would expect to see clusters of agent's with similar
behaviour, and that clustering will increase population density and
therefore lower the fitness of agent's in that cluster. So there is a
form of fitness sharing going on, but as I say, I haven't really
thought through the implications and dynamics of that. But it would be
interesting to set up, play with and observe what happens.

Factoring in behavioural space considerations should be possible at a
later date, e.g. fitness at a geo-location is not adjusted down if an
agent has novel behaviour compared to other agent's at that
geo-location.

As per usual - any thoughts and feedback are welcome.

Colin
